children.name: new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  recently made, built, produced, or invented:
examples: ▪ They pulled down the movie theater and built a new health club on the site.
▪ the new issue of ‘Time’ magazine
▪ Porsche’s newest sports car will be unveiled at next week’s Motor Show.
brand newcompletely new
▪ Apparently there’s going to be a brand new ‘James Bond’ movie out in the spring.
as good as new: gần như mới
▪ By the time we’d finished painting the boat, it looked as good as new.

children.name: latest
children.definition: /ˈleɪtɪst, ˈleɪtəst/  the latest film/book/model/fashion etc the film, book etc that has been produced or made most recently:
examples: mới nhất, gần đây nhất
▪ Have you seen Spielberg’s latest movie?
▪ the latest fashions from the Paris catwalks

children.name: be just out
children.definition: /biː ˌdʒʌst ˈaʊt/  if a book, record, or film is just out, it has only recently arrived in the shops, cinemas etc:
examples: vừa mới ra mắt
▪ REM’s new album is just out.

children.name: recent
children.definition: /ˈriːsənt/  a recent film, book etc is one that was made or produced only a short time ago:
examples: ▪ The recent movie version of the book was not a big success.
▪ There will be an exhibition of his most recent work at the Tate Gallery, starting this Saturday.
▪ A recent study of Open University graduates found that students aged 60 - 65 had better results than any other age group.

children.name: be hot off the press
children.definition: /biː ˌhɒt ɒf ðə ˈpresǁ-ˌhɑːt-/  if abookis hot off the press, it has only just become available to the public, so that anyone who has it is one of the first people to read it:
examples: ▪ People were queuing up for the new Harry Potter book to arrive - hot off the press.

children.name: instead of the one that you had before
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  your new job, home etc is the one you got most recently, and is different from the one you had before:
examples: ▪ Don’t forget to give me your new address.
▪ Have you met Keith’s new girlfriend?
▪ After the divorce, she went off to Canada to start a new life.

children.name: another
children.definition: /əˈnʌðəʳ/  if you want another job, another house etc, you want it instead of the one that you have now:
examples: ▪ After ten years with the same firm I decided it was time to look for another job.
▪ If you don’t like one doctor, you can ask to see another.

children.name: replace
children.definition: /rɪˈpleɪs/  if you replace something that is old or damaged, you put a new one in its place to be used instead of it:
examples: ▪ I’ll have to replace my car soon - this one’s done 130,000 miles.
▪ The roof was in such bad condition that it needed to be completely replaced.
replace something with something
▪ They’re replacing the old windows with modern ones.

children.name: new ideas or ways of doing things
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  new ideas or ways of doing things that did not exist before or had not been thought of before:
examples: ▪ Does anyone have any new ideas?
new ways/methods of doing something
▪ The hospital is doing a lot of research into new ways of treating asthma.
▪ It’s vital that we find new methods of producing and conserving energy.

children.name: original
children.definition: /əˈrɪdʒɪnəl, əˈrɪdʒənəl, -dʒənəl/  completely different from anything that has been thought of before:
examples: original idea/design/style: độc đáo
▪ My job is to think up creative and original advertising ideas
completely original
▪ Woolf’s writing was completely original - nothing like it had ever been done before.
▪ a jazz musician with a completely original style
highly original
▪ I was impressed by the highly original design of the house.

children.name: revolutionary
children.definition: /ˌrevəˈluːʃənəriǁ-ʃəneri/  a revolutionary idea, method, or invention is completely different from anything that existed before, and is likely to bring importantchangesor improvements:
examples: cách mạng
▪ Einstein’s revolutionary theories made people look at the universe in a completely new way.
▪ revolutionary technology for producing cheap, pollution-free energy
▪ The new treatment for cancer is considered revolutionary.

children.name: innovative
children.definition: /ˈɪnəˌveɪtɪv/  an innovative design, idea, plan etc is new, different and better than those that existed before, and shows a lot of imagination:
examples: đổi mới
▪ The city has introduced an innovative system of traffic control.
▪ When it was first introduced, the electric car was described as one of the ten most innovative products of the year.
highly innovative
▪ The idea for the programme ‘Big Brother’ was highly innovative.

children.name: innovation
children.definition: /ˌɪnəˈveɪʃən/  something such as a new idea, method, or system that has never been thought of before, especially one that is better than previous ones :
examples: đổi mới cách tân
▪ The kids-only Internet service is a great innovation which will help parents control their children’s access to the Internet.
technological innovations
▪ All the latest technological innovations of cinema were used to create the special effects.
communication/software etc innovations
▪ What exactly will the impact of all these communication innovations be?

children.name: fresh
children.definition: /freʃ/  a fresh idea, approach etc is new and different from previous ones, and may help todealwitha problem:
examples: ▪ We need a fresh approach to this problem.
▪ The negotiations won’t make any progress unless one of the sides puts forward fresh proposals.
▪ Toy manufacturers are always on the lookout for fresh ideas.

children.name: novel
children.definition: /ˈnɒvəlǁˈnɑː-/  a novel idea, method etc is new andinterestingbecause it isunexpectedand different from what has existed before:
examples: mới lạ
▪ Scientists have come up with a novel way of catching fish.
▪ Tonight’s TV news will be presented in a novel format.
▪ I spent six months living in a monastery in northern India, which was a novel experience.

children.name: novelty
children.definition: /ˈnɒvəltiǁˈnɑː-/  something that is interesting because it is new and unusual, especially when this makes people think it is not very serious:
examples: vật mới lạ
▪ Retail analysts say that electronic shopping remains a novelty for most peopleit is a novelty for somebody to do something
▪ It was a novelty for people at college to see a student with two kids.
be something of a noveltyseem new and unusual
▪ Fast-food restaurants like McDonald’s are still something of a novelty in Moscow.
novelty[uncountable noun] the quality that makes something interesting because it is new and unusual:tính mới lạ
the novelty of something :
▪ I was still enjoying the novelty of being married, and referring to Jenny as ‘my wife’.
the novelty wears offit stops seeming new and unusual
▪ I loved driving to work at first, but the novelty soon wore off.

children.name: pioneering
children.definition: /ˌpaɪəˈnɪərɪŋ◂/  pioneering work, research, efforts etc introduce completely new ways of doing things, which are later followed and developed by other people:
examples: tiên phong
▪ Moore’s pioneering work on semiconductors has made him perhaps the most famous figure in Silicon Valley.
▪ Pioneering research shows that the experiences of childhood help form the brain’s circuits for music and maths, language and emotion.

children.name: be in its infancy
children.definition: /biː ɪn ɪts ˈɪnfənsi/  if a science or a new area of knowledge or study is in its infancy, people have just begun to find out more about it, to work with it etc:
examples: trong giai đoạn phôi thai
▪ The science of cybernetics is still in its infancy.
▪ These rockets were built at a time when space technology was in its infancy.

children.name: new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  a new organization, government etc hasonlyexistedfor a short time:
examples: ▪ Within weeks of the election, the new government announced big tax cuts.
▪ Thousands of new businesses are set up each year.
▪ one of Europe’s newest TV stations

children.name: young
children.definition: /jʌŋ/  a young company or country is one which has not existed for very long and has not yet fully developed:
examples: non trẻ
▪ Most banks are keen to loan money to promising young businesses.
▪ ‘Impact’ is a lively young company which specializes in public relations.
▪ As a country, Zimbabwe is still quite young.

children.name: start-up
children.definition: /ˈstɑːʳt ʌp/  a start-up company is a new company that has recently been started, especially one that uses computers and the Internet:
examples: ▪ Several start-up Net companies saw their share prices rocket in the first few years, only to see them plunge as the recession hit.
start-up[countable noun] a start-up company:
▪ There were 4000 start-ups in Silicon Valley in 1998.

children.name: sb who has just started a new job, school etc
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  someone who is new has only recently arrived in a place, started working in a particular job, or joined an organization:
examples: ▪ You’re new here, ’t you?aren
▪ All new employees are given training.
new to
▪ Children who are new to the school may need extra help
▪ We don’t expect you to work as fast as everyone else, while you’re still new to the job.
new recruit; lính mới , tân binh
▪ Our club membership is flourishing - we’ve had a huge number of new recruits this year.

children.name: newcomer
children.definition: /ˈnjuːkʌməʳǁˈnuː-/  someone who has only recently arrived in a place or only recently started a job, sport, or other activity:
examples: người mới đến
▪ The inhabitants of these remote mountain villages tend to be very suspicious of newcomers.
▪ Our team will include some familiar faces as well as a few newcomers.
newcomer to
▪ Although she’s a newcomer to the sport, she’s already very successful.
comparative/relative newcomersomeone who has arrived or started doing something recently, compared to other people
▪ I was fifty and a comparative newcomer to computers.

children.name: new arrival
children.definition: /ˌnjuː əˈraɪvəlǁˌnuː-/  someone who has just arrived in a place, especially in order to live or work there:
examples: người mới đến
▪ Jim, this is our new arrival, Lyndsay. She’ll be taking over from Bob.
▪ 1200 new arrivals, including small children and babies, were left sitting on the pavement outside the embassy.
the new arrivala newly-born baby
▪ Gwyn’s children, Craig and Laura, are thrilled with the new arrival.

children.name: stranger
children.definition: /ˈstreɪndʒəʳ/  someone who has just arrived in a place which they have never been to before, and which they do not know much about:
examples: người lạ
▪ The people I stayed with were very kind, so I didn’t feel like a stranger for long.
▪ Many of the farming families have lived here for hundreds of years, and tend to treat everyone else as strangers.

children.name: fresh
children.definition: /freʃ/  someone who isfreshfroma place ofeducationhas only just finished training and is not experienced when they arrive at a new job:
examples: vừa mới đến từ
fresh from
▪ You can’t expect teachers fresh from college to deal with large classes of difficult children.
fresh out of
▪ We were under the command of a young lieutenant who was fresh out of officer training school.

children.name: rookie
children.definition: /ˈrʊki/  American someone who has just started doing a job or playing a professional sport, and has little experience:
examples: ▪ It was rookie coach, Ray Rhodes, who got the most credit for keeping the team in check.
▪ a rookie cop

children.name: fresher
children.definition: British /freshmanAmerican /ˈfreʃəʳ, ˈfreʃmən/  a student who has just started at auniversityorcollege:
examples: sinh viên mới, sinh viên năm nhất
▪ I was eighteen years old and a freshman at Harvard.
▪ a freshers’ party
▪ freshers’ week

children.name: newbie
children.definition: /ˈnjuːbiǁˈnuː-/ informalsomeone who is a new user of a technology, especially the Internet:
examples: người mới dùng
▪ The program is simple to use, even for newbies.

children.name: new blood
children.definition: /ˌnjuː ˈblʌdǁˌnuː-/  someone whostarts a new joborjoinsanorganizationand is likely to makeimprovements, for example by introducing more modern ideas and methods:
examples: dòng máu mới
▪ They seem to be expecting everyone over 50 to step aside and make way for new blood.
▪ After its membership halved in the past year, leaving mainly diehard right-wingers behind, the party now desperately needs new blood.

children.name: recently bought, or not used before
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  recently bought, or not used or owned by anyone before:
examples: ▪ New and second-hand books for sale.
▪ Do you like my new dress?
▪ That’s a nice jacket - is it new?
buy something new
▪ I’d like to get a video camera but I can’t afford to buy one new.

children.name: brand new
children.definition: /ˌbrænd ˈnjuː◂ǁ-ˈnuː◂/  use this when you want to make it very clear that something has notbeenusedorownedby anyone before:
examples: mới toanh
▪ My brother’s just bought a brand new BMW.
▪ When did you buy this sofa? It looks completely brand new.

children.name: fresh
children.definition: /freʃ/  clean or new andnot used before:
examples: mới
fresh sheet
▪ You’ll have to start again on a fresh sheet of paper.fresh page
▪ Please start each new question on a fresh page.
fresh towel
▪ The service at the hotel was amazing. We even had fresh towels every morning.
fresh clothes
▪ I’m just going to have a shower and put on some fresh clothes.

children.name: food and drink that is new and still tastes good
fresh
children.definition: /freʃ/  fresh food has been recently made, killed, or picked, and it still tastes good:
examples: tươi mới
▪ Fresh fish tastes completely different to fish that has been frozen.
▪ Do you think this meat smells fresh?
fresh from the oven/sea/garden
▪ The restaurant claims that all the vegetables used in its recipes are picked fresh from the garden every day.
freshly [adverb]
▪ freshly baked bread

children.name: okay/OK/all right
children.definition: /əʊˈkeɪ, ɔːl ˈraɪt/ spokenfresh enough to eat:
examples: ổn
▪ I’m not sure that these eggs are still okay.
▪ The milk looked all right, but when I tasted it, it was horrible.
okay etc to eat/drink
▪ It’s been kept in the refrigerator, so it should still be okay to eat.

children.name: something that has just been discovered
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/
examples: ▪ Scientists have found a new oilfield off the coast of Norway.
▪ Her lawyers have come up with new evidence that may prove her innocence.
▪ Important new discoveries in the field of radiology may lead to a breakthrough in the treatment of cancer.

children.name: newly discovered
children.definition: /ˌnjuːli dɪˈskʌvəʳd◂ǁˌnuːli-/  a newly discovered object, place, piece of information etc has been discovered very recently:
examples: ▪ The newly discovered planets around distant stars are similar to Jupiter in size.
▪ Howard was working on the translation of a newly discovered novel by Jules Verne.
▪ Newly discovered evidence showed that there had been a miscarriage of justice.

children.name: fresh
children.definition: /freʃ/  fresh evidence/informationevidenceorinformationthat is new and adds to or changes what is already known about the situation:
examples: mới
▪ Police say they are still hoping for fresh information about the missing girl.
▪ The judge told the court that the fresh evidence could be of considerable significance.

children.name: experiences and feelings that you have never had before
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/
examples: ▪ When I first left home, I enjoyed the new feeling of independence.
a whole new experience
▪ Living in the city was a whole new experience for Philip.

children.name: newfound
children.definition: /ˈnjuːfaʊndǁˈnuː-/  newfound confidence, interest etc are feelings or qualities that you have gained veryrecently:
examples: ▪ Encouraged by their success, the rebel forces advanced with newfound confidence.
▪ She went back to her work full of newfound enthusiasm.
▪ When I retired, it took me a while to enjoy my newfound freedom.
